¯ows and their deposits

text: ABSTRACT

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
The complexity of ¯ow and wide variety of depositional processes operating in
subaqueous density ¯ows, combined with post-depositional consolidation
and soft-sediment deformation, often make it dif®cult to interpret the
characteristics of the original ¯ow from the sedimentary record. This has led
to considerable confusion of nomenclature in the literature. This paper
attempts to clarify this situation by presenting a simple classi®cation of
sedimentary density ¯ows, based on physical ¯ow properties and grain-
support mechanisms, and brie¯y discusses the likely characteristics of the
deposited sediments. Cohesive ¯ows are commonly referred to as debris ¯ows
and mud ¯ows and de®ned on the basis of sediment characteristics. The
boundary between cohesive and non-cohesive density ¯ows (frictional ¯ows) is
poorly constrained, but dimensionless numbers may be of use to de®ne ¯ow
thresholds. Frictional ¯ows include a continuous series from sediment slides to
turbidity currents. Subdivision of these ¯ows is made on the basis of the
dominant particle-support mechanisms, which include matrix strength (in
cohesive ¯ows), buoyancy, pore pressure, grain-to-grain interaction (causing
dispersive pressure), Reynolds stresses (turbulence) and bed support (particles
moved on the stationary bed). The dominant particle-support mechanism
depends upon ¯ow conditions, particle concentration, grain-size distribution
and particle type. In hyperconcentrated density ¯ows, very high sediment
concentrations (>25 volume%) make particle interactions of major importance.
The difference between hyperconcentrated density ¯ows and cohesive ¯ows is
that
the
former
are
friction
dominated.
With
decreasing
sediment
concentration, vertical particle sorting can result from differential settling,
and ¯ows in which this can occur are termed concentrated density ¯ows. The
boundary between hyperconcentrated and concentrated density ¯ows is
de®ned by a change in particle behaviour, such that denser or larger grains
are no longer fully supported by grain interaction, thus allowing coarse-grain
tail (or dense-grain tail) normal grading. The concentration at which this
change occurs depends on particle size, sorting, composition and relative
density,
so
that
a
single
threshold
concentration
cannot
be
de®ned.
Concentrated density ¯ows may be highly erosive and subsequently deposit
complete
or
incomplete
Lowe
and
Bouma
sequences.
Conversely,
hydroplaning at the base of debris ¯ows, and possibly also in some
hyperconcentrated ¯ows, may reduce the ¯uid drag, thus allowing high ¯ow
velocities while preventing large-scale erosion. Flows with concentrations <9%
by volume are true turbidity ¯ows (sensu Bagnold, 1962), in which ¯uid
turbulence is the main particle-support mechanism. Turbidity ¯ows and
concentrated density ¯ows can be subdivided on the basis of ¯ow duration into

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
instantaneous surges, longer duration surge-like ¯ows and quasi-steady
currents. Flow duration is shown to control the nature of the resulting
deposits. Surge-like turbidity currents tend to produce classical Bouma
sequences, whose nature at any one site depends on factors such as ¯ow
size, sediment type and proximity to source. In contrast, quasi-steady turbidity
currents, generated by hyperpycnal river ef¯uent, can deposit coarsening-up
units capped by ®ning-up units (because of waxing and waning conditions
respectively) and may also include thick units of uniform character (resulting
from prolonged periods of near-steady conditions). Any ¯ow type may
progressively change character along the transport path, with transformation
primarily
resulting
from
reductions
in sediment
concentration
through
progressive entrainment of surrounding ¯uid and/or sediment deposition.
The rate of ¯uid entrainment, and consequently ¯ow transformation, is
dependent on factors including slope gradient, lateral con®nement, bed
roughness, ¯ow thickness and water depth. Flows with high and low
sediment concentrations may co-exist in one transport event because of
down¯ow transformations, ¯ow strati®cation or shear layer development of the
mixing interface with the overlying water (mixing cloud formation). Deposits
of an individual ¯ow event at one site may therefore form from a succession
of different ¯ow types, and this introduces considerable complexity into
classifying the ¯ow event or component ¯ow types from the deposits.

text: INTRODUCTION

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
Density ¯ows are important sediment-transport-
ing mechanisms and have long been recognized
as major factors in the construction of deep-sea
fans and deltas (Bates, 1953; Prior & Coleman,
1982). Density ¯ows contribute to formation of
canyons and channel-levee systems and distal
depositional lobes (Normark & Piper, 1972; Mutti,
1992) and are important on slope aprons (Piper,
1978; Stow, 1984a) and basin plains (Gorsline,
1978; Pilkey et al., 1980; Stow, 1984b), partic-
ularly when compared with the slow rate of
hemipelagic sedimentation. The de®nitive im-
portance of sediment ¯ows in forming submarine
sedimentary fans and sediment lobes has been
demonstrated through the model of fan growth
developed by Normark (1970). The Grand Banks
`turbidity current' on the Laurentian Fan that was
triggered by an earthquake (Heezen & Ewing,
1952; Kuenen, 1952) demonstrated that large
¯ow-slides
could
generate
turbulent,
gravity-
driven sediment ¯ows in the ocean. Flows along
the sea-¯oor are economically important because
their motion or triggering mechanisms can cause
industrial, environmental and human disasters

text:
such as pipeline or cable breaks, e.g. Grand
Banks, 1929 (Heezen & Ewing, 1952), Nice, 1979
(Gennesseaux et al., 1980) and tsunamis, e.g.
Grand Banks, 1929 (Dawson, 1999), Nice, 1979
(Gennesseaux et al., 1980). Their deposits in the
rock record may also form signi®cant hydrocar-
bon reservoirs.
Despite, or possibly because of, their import-
ance
in different
areas,
the
classi®cation of
subaqueous density currents is confused. Various
classi®cation schemes for offshore density ¯ows
and their deposits have been proposed at various
times and for different purposes, such as for the
description of hydrocarbon reservoir rocks or to
assist in the understanding of ¯uid dynamics in
modern oceans. As a consequence, these schemes
are based on ¯ow behaviour (Middleton & Hamp-
ton, 1973; Nardin et al., 1979), description of
ancient deposits (Guibaudo, 1992) or an attempt
to interpret ¯ow behaviour from ancient deposits
(Lowe, 1982; Pickering et al., 1989; Lowe & Guy,
2000). The same descriptive terms using various
quali®cations have been used to de®ne different
processes or products (Shanmugam, 1996). Con-
versely, the same processes can be named differ-
ently according to different authors (see Fig. 1).

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
Fig. 1. Terminology and usage of ¯ow type nomenclature according to sediment concentration as a percentage by
volume. Many of the published limits are quoted as weight per cent but, as both water and sediment density varies,
volume per cent is perhaps more useful. Consequently, the published weight percentages have been converted
assuming a water density of 1000 kg m3 and a sediment density equivalent to quartz. In many cases, a single
sediment concentration cannot be de®ned as the boundary conditions, because the threshold volume per cent
depends on other factors such as clay content. The ranges of possible conditions for boundaries are represented by
dashed lines.

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
This has led to some very casual uses, and
frequent misuses, of terminology in the geological
literature, which has, in turn, led to controversy
and disagreement. This is illustrated, for exam-
ple, by the vigorous discussions between Hiscott
(1994, 1995) and Sohn (1995, 1997) and Falk &
Dorsey (1998) and Sohn (1999), which arose
partly because of different usage of the terms
`turbidity current' and `traction carpet'. Some of
the problems with terminology are discussed
brie¯y below to present the background for
classi®cation.

text:
INCONSISTENCIES IN PUBLISHED
CLASSIFICATIONS AND TERMINOLOGY
OF SEDIMENTARY DENSITY FLOWS

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
Bouma (1962) provided a model to explain the
relationship
between
sedimentary
structures
and grain-size variation in turbidites and the
depositional
processes
in
turbidity
currents.
Simultaneously, Bagnold (1962) demonstrated
that turbulent, gravity-driven currents could be
maintained only for very-low-volume concentra-
tions (C < 9%). Middleton & Hampton (1973), in

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
agreement with Bagnold's observations, de®ned
turbidity currents as `sediment gravity ¯ows in
which the sediment is supported mainly by the
upward component of ¯uid turbulence' (Fig. 1).
Density ¯ows with such low sediment concen-
trations tend to have low competence and cannot
transport coarse sand or gravel over any signi®-
cant distances (kilometres) except on steep slopes
(over a few degrees). As a consequence, many of
the coarse-grained beds that have been called
turbidites in the literature cannot have been
deposited by turbidity currents sensu Middleton
& Hampton (1973).
Lowe (1982) addressed part of this problem by
considering deposits with distinctly different
character to Bouma sequences and attributed
them to `high-density turbidity currents'. These
sequences are called Lowe sequences in the
present paper. It is unlikely that Lowe sequences
can form from true turbidity currents because of
their low sediment concentrations and conse-
quent low sedimentation rates but, as suggested
by Lowe (1982), these sequences must have been
deposited from ¯ows with higher sediment con-
centrations at least near the base of the ¯ow. The
term `high-density turbidity current', as Shanmu-
gam (1996) has pointed out, causes misunder-
standing. The term `turbidity current' has been
used in the literature for ¯ows with sediment
volume concentrations up to 45% (e.g. Kuenen,
1966; Middleton, 1967; Fig. 1). For this range of
concentration values far above the Bagnold limit,
¯uid turbulence does not wholly support all the
particles within the ¯ow, and grain-to-grain inter-
action becomes an increasingly important support
mechanism (Kneller & Branney, 1995). These
¯ows are not turbidity currents sensu Middleton
& Hampton (1973). In an attempt to resolve the
problem of terminology and de®nition, Shanmu-
gam (1996) reclassi®ed deposits previously called
high-density turbidity current deposits (or high-
density turbidites) as sandy debris-¯ow deposits.
However, this rede®nition creates a new problem
because, from a geotechnical (rheological) point of
view, debris ¯ows are unequivocally cohesive
¯ows, whereas ¯ows involving relatively non-
cohesive particles (e.g. sandy ¯ows, debris aval-
anches) are frictional ¯ows in which cohesion is
low. Debris ¯ows and mud ¯ows have been
de®ned as those ¯ows in which particles of
various sizes (up to boulders several metres in
diameter)
are
transported
because
of
matrix
strength (e.g. Nardin et al., 1979; Lowe, 1982).
Iverson (1997) considered that the presence of
high pore pressures was a phenomenon that

distinguished debris ¯ows from other ¯ow types,
and Major & Iverson (1999) supported this theory
with experimental data, although it is debatable
whether these subaerial, low-mud-content ¯ows
are comparable with the marine cohesive ¯ows
discussed here. Rheological models for debris-
¯ow
behaviour
and
motion
show
that
¯ow
strength is related to ¯ow viscosity (i.e. the
viscosity of the sediment±water mixture: Bing-
ham viscosity) in a Bingham model (®rst pro-
posed by Johnson, 1970):

where s is the internal shear stress, du/dz is the
rate of shear (in the vertical direction), K is the
Bingham yield stress and gb is the Bingham
viscosity. Alternate ¯ow strength is related to
both viscosity and cohesion in a Coulomb viscous
model (Hampton, 1972; Schwab et al., 1996):

2

text:
where rn is the effective normal stress, / is the
angle of internal friction of the sediment, g is the
dynamic viscosity of the sediment±¯uid mixture
and c is the cohesive (non-frictional) component
of strength. The Herschel±Bulkley model is sim-
ilar to the Bingham model but with the rate of
shear raised to a power n, where n varies from
about 1/3 to 1, depending on the concentration
and type of suspension (cf. Coussot & Proust,
1996).
The common direct comparison between sub-
aqueous
and
subaerial
debris
¯ows
may
be
misleading, as ¯ow properties may be consider-
ably different. First, water aids subaerial ¯ow
(Major & Iverson, 1999; Vallance, 2000) by adding
additional
mass
(contributing
to
the
density
contrast between ¯ow and ambient ¯uid). Sec-
ondly, water supplies additional pore pressure
and also, to some extent, acts to hold the ¯ow
together by surface tension effects. In contrast, the
water phase within subaqueous ¯ows does not
add signi®cantly to the density contrast between
the ¯ow and surrounding ¯uid; hence, it supplies
no driving force. The water within subaqueous
¯ows is continuous with the ambient ¯uid;
surface tension is less important and, hence, it
does not act to hold ¯ows together, making
entrainment
of
ambient
¯uid
easier.
Conse-
quently, subaerial ¯ows with very low percent-
ages of mud may behave as debris ¯ows, but the
same sediment mixtures would be unlikely to
behave in this manner if under water. Lowe &

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
Guy
(2000),
studying
the
Lower
Cretaceous
marine Britannia Formation, interpreted some
unusual
beds
that
exhibit
evidence
of
both
turbulent and cohesive sediment-support mecha-
nisms as deposits of ¯ows that were transitional
between turbidity currents and cohesive debris
¯ows. They termed these muddy sand-rich ¯ows
`slurry ¯ows' but used that term in a different way
from that used for subaerial ¯ows (cf. Pierson &
Costa, 1987) and considered them more akin to
subaerial hyperconcentrated ¯ows.
Another area of disagreement in published
classi®cation schemes is the boundaries of the
`low-density
turbidity
current'
class.
Kuenen
(1952) applied this term to a very narrow range
of conditions, whereas Middleton (1967, 1993)
used it for a much wider range of sediment
concentrations (Fig. 1). Confusion may also have
arisen from the literature because of the use of
sediment concentration terms such as volume per
cent and weight per cent, and the associated
problem of differentiating density and concentra-
tion. Concentration de®nes the proportion of the
¯ow that is composed of sedimentary particles
and is best de®ned by volume per cent. In
contrast, the density of the ¯ow is de®ned by its
mass divided by its volume and so relates to both
the density of the ¯uid component and the
density and concentration of the solid component
(thus the use of weight per cent). Considerable
confusion
arises
where
the
concentration
of
sediment is referred to as density (as in number
of particles per unit volume). Volume per cent is
used throughout this paper. If the water within
the ¯ow and the ambient ¯uid have the same
temperature and salinity (often not the case), then
the bulk density of the ¯ow, qf, is related to the
sediment volume concentration of the ¯ow, C, by

qf  qs ÿ qwC  qw
3

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
where qw is the density of the ambient ¯uid and qs
is the density of the sediment grains.
It is essential to compare like with like in order
to improve the general understanding of deposi-
tional processes, density ¯ow behaviour and
occurrence of different types of ¯ow. Currently,
it is dif®cult to be sure of comparing like with like
when reading published descriptions, and greater
consensus on terminology is needed. Calling
the whole range of sand and gravel subaqueous
gravity
¯ow
deposits
turbidites
(even
with
subdivision) may obscure differences that may
have signi®cant importance
to,
for example,
hydrocarbon reservoir development. For example,

text:
Kneller (1995) suggests that quasi-steady ¯ow
deposits will have different characteristics and
distribution from surge-type ¯ow deposits, but
how many sedimentologists or geologists could
distinguish them in a borehole and understand
the implications of what they interpret? Attempts
to improve classi®cation, such as presented here,
may help subsequent research to focus on key
scienti®c questions (some of which are highligh-
ted in this paper), even though no such simple
classi®cation scheme is ever likely to de®ne such
a complex system to everyone's satisfaction. Only
a few of the ideas presented here are new, and this
paper pulls together disparate ideas from numer-
ous sources in an attempt to produce a more
uni®ed
classi®cation
scheme
for
subaqueous
sedimentary density ¯ows and their deposits.
Most natural gravity ¯ows are strati®ed (verti-
cal variation in sediment concentration, particle
type, water density) to some extent because of
ambient ¯uid entrainment and grain settling
(GarcõÂa & Parker, 1993; GarcõÂa, 1994; Altinakar
et al., 1996). In addition, their character varies in
the ¯ow direction (non-uniform) and with time
(unsteady), so that a single ¯ow may have
components that are classi®ed differently, and
the proportions of those components vary with
time.
Consequently,
the
classi®cation
system
presented here may be more useful as a mechan-
ism for focusing thought and aiding teaching and
discussion than as the solution to classifying all
real world examples.

text:
A SIMPLIFIED CLASSIFICATION
OF SUBAQUEOUS SEDIMENT-
TRANSPORTING DENSITY FLOWS

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
This paper presents a simpli®ed classi®cation of
subaqueous sedimentary density ¯ows, based on
recent research, in an attempt to overcome some
of the problems of earlier classi®cation schemes.
The new classi®cation is based on the cohesivity
of particles, ¯ow duration, sediment concentra-
tion
and
particle-support
mechanism.
The
classi®cation attempts to formalize terminology,
establish the basis for de®ning debris ¯ows and
mud ¯ows, establish criteria for distinguishing
hyperconcentrated, concentrated and turbidity
¯ows
and
makes
the
important
distinction
between
surge-like
¯ows
and
quasi-steady
currents. Flows in which the density of the
water phase is the cause of the density excess
(e.g. saline gravity currents) are not considered
here.

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
Subaqueous sediment-transportingdensity¯ows
can be subdivided according to the density
difference between the ¯ow (qf) and the sur-
rounding water (qw). This allows the de®nition of
four ¯ow types (Fig. 2): over¯ow (hypopycnal
¯ow) if qf < qw; homopycnal ¯ow if qf  qw;
under¯ow (hyperpycnal ¯ow) if qf > qw; and
mesopycnal ¯ow (intra¯ow or intrusive ¯ow) if
qf is between the density of two layers in a
strati®ed water column so that ¯ow travels above
a pycnocline (cf. Bates, 1953; Mulder et al.,
1997a). This classi®cation system is a simpli®ca-
tion, as ambient turbulence can turn hyperpycnal
or hypopycnal ¯ows into homopycnal ¯ows.
Hypopycnal ¯ows are important near the mouths
of many rivers where sediment is dispersed in
buoyant plumes (cf. Nemec, 1995). Mesopycnal
¯ows are particularly important in strongly stra-
ti®ed marine basins where density contrasts
between water layers are large (Rimoldi et al.,
1996) and in thermally layered lakes (Nemec,
1995). Density ¯ows that transport large volumes
of sediment to deep water are probably mostly
under¯ows and, consequently, this paper con-
centrates on these. In modern usage (and in this
paper), hyperpycnal ¯ow is used to refer to
under¯ows generated directly from ¯uvial ef¯u-

Fig. 3. Schematic de®nition diagram for subaqueous
sedimentary density ¯ows, indicating dominant grain-
support
mechanisms,
idealized
velocity
pro®les,
idealized ¯ow shape and schematic sedimentary logs.
Two types of hyperconcentrated density ¯ows are
presented to represent end-members depending on
load characteristics. Two types of concentrated density
¯ows represent the large range of sediment concentra-
tions in this category and the associated variation in
sediment types. Turbidity ¯ows are subdivided into
three classes depending on ¯ow duration. Diagram-
matic velocity pro®les for positions within each ¯ow
(near the ¯ow front) are presented to show inferred
variation between ¯ow types. No relative magnitude is
implied, as all ¯ow types occur on a large range of
scales. Two velocity pro®les are presented for debris
¯ows to illustrate the difference between plug and non-
plug ¯ow conditions. The sedimentary logs are highly
schematic to indicate the nature of variation between
deposit types.

ent and not for density ¯ows generated wholly
within the marine basin. In both hyperpycnal and
mesopycnal ¯ow, the density of the ¯uid phase in
the ¯ow may be less than that of the ambient
water, and sediment settling may lead to upper
surface convection or head lofting (cf. Sparks
et al., 1993; Rimoldi et al., 1996).

Sedimentary density under¯ows are subdivi-
ded according to their rheological behaviour,
making the major distinction between predomin-

text:
antly cohesive and frictional ¯ows (Fig. 3). Cohe-
sive ¯ows have matrix strength resulting from
cohesion between particles (usually ®ne grained).

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
The cohesive strength resists the penetration of
water into the ¯ow, maintaining the coherence of
the ¯ow body. In contrast, frictional (non-cohe-
sive) ¯ows are made up of discrete particles and
can develop high porosity (intergranular space)
during ¯ow, which, in subaqueous environments,
is predominantly ®lled with water. The behaviour
of frictional ¯ows is thus related directly to the
relative proportion of grains and water, which can
vary greatly during the run-out of a frictional
¯ow, because there is little or no cohesive force
between grains to prevent water ingress. The
transition between sediment slides and sediment
¯ows, and their classi®cation, have been dis-
cussed by Mulder & Cochonat (1996).
The subdivision of subaqueous frictional ¯ows
is primarily based on sediment concentration,
with
three
main
classes:
hyperconcentrated
density ¯ows, concentrated density ¯ows and
turbidity currents. This approach is distinctly
different from that of Kneller & Buckee (2000),
who group all ¯ows `induced by the action of
gravity upon a (¯uidal) turbid mixture of ¯uid
and (suspended) sediment, by virtue of the density
difference between the mixture and the ambient
¯uid' as suspension currents. The subdivision of
frictional ¯ows is attempted because of observed
variations in ¯ow behaviour at differing sediment
concentrations (e.g. Hallworth & Huppert, 1998)
and differing deposit characteristics. The class
boundaries are
de®ned on the
basis of the
dominant particle-support mechanism. The term
hyperconcentrated density ¯ow is preferred to the
terms `frictional debris ¯ows' or `sandy debris
¯ows' of Shanmugam (1996) to make a clear
distinction from the term `cohesive debris ¯ow'.
As a consequence, the term `debris ¯ow' can be
used synonymously for `cohesive debris ¯ow'
(Fig. 3). Hyperconcentrated density ¯ows may
transform into concentrated density ¯ows and
turbidity ¯ows, as there is no proven gap between
the sediment concentration ranges of the three
types of frictional ¯ow.
The Bagnold limit for turbulent suspension
(C  9%) is used to separate turbidity ¯ows sensu
stricto from concentrated density ¯ows. Accurate
application of the Bagnold limit may be dif®cult
(or impossible) in the ®eld because of the uncer-
tainty regarding the nature of deposits from ¯ows
on either side of the limit and the continuum of
¯ow behaviour. It is possible that sediment will
move differently during emplacement on the bed,
and so grain fabric in the deposits might vary, but
this has yet to be studied experimentally. At the
moment, it is only possible to infer that deposits

text:
are from ¯ows in which ¯uid turbulence was the
dominant particle-support mechanism (turbidity
currents sensu lato: cf. Fig. 4), rather than the only
support mechanism (turbidity currents sensu
stricto), on the basis of grain size and sedimentary
structures (e.g. ripple cross-lamination; cf. Lowe,
1988). Well-developed normal vertical grading
may be typical of suspension deposits from a
turbulence-dominated ¯ow. This classi®cation
boundary therefore highlights a scienti®c question
that has not been addressed, although the out-
come has been assumed in earlier classi®cations:
is there a difference in the deposits across the
threshold where grain interaction starts?
The boundary distinction between hypercon-
centrated and concentrated density ¯ows is dif®-
cult to de®ne for either the ¯ows or the deposits.
As with turbidity ¯ows and concentrated density
¯ows, the boundary should be based on a physical
threshold related to particle support. Such a
threshold is likely to correlate with a change
in deposit character, although in the deposits
depositional features may be overprinted by
post-depositional features such as soft-sediment
deformation structures that make classi®cation of
¯ow type impossible. The boundary proposed
here is a threshold of sediment concentration
when particle sorting can occur freely by particle
settling during the passage of the ¯ow. This
boundary is close to, but may not be identical
with, the transition between Newtonian and non-
Newtonian conditions. There is little or no normal
grading
in
hyperconcentrated
¯ow
deposits
except at the very top of the deposit where
deposition occurs from the more dilute mixing
cloud. Julien & Lan (1991) showed that the
rheology of hyperconcentrated ¯ows depends
not only on the particle concentration but also
on the densities of the ¯uid and solid particles and
particle size. Consequently, a single concentration
is not easily de®nable as the boundary (see Fig. 1).
This classi®cation includes a wide range (con-
tinuum) of ¯ow types within the concentrated
density ¯ow category. Many deposits can be
con®dently interpreted as derived from concen-
trated density ¯ows (cf. the high density currents
described by Lowe, 1982), and this overcomes the
misunderstanding that arises from earlier classi-
®cations using the terms `high density' and
`turbidity' when density and sediment concen-
tration were unknown and ¯uid turbulence was
not the major support mechanism. The processes
of deposition in concentrated density ¯ows, and
the nature of the resulting deposits, are poorly
understood. For example, the stability ®elds of

Fig. 4. Diagram to illustrate changes during transformation of marine sediment ¯ows from hyperconcentrated
density ¯ow to concentrated density ¯ow and then to surge-like turbidity ¯ow. Sediment concentration decreases
progressively with distance, although the shape of the curve presented is speculative, and it may be steeper, for
example, at the transition from hyperconcentrated to concentrated density ¯ow. The graph also shows the major
particle-support mechanisms operating and demonstrates part of the basis for distinguishing between ¯ow types.
Turbidity ¯ows are de®ned sensu lato as where ¯uid turbulence is the dominant, rather than the sole, particle-
support mechanism.

text:
sedimentary bedforms at high sedimentation rates
are not well known (cf. Lowe, 1988), and the
conditions for, and behaviour of, traction carpets
and mobile bed layers are subject to considerable
debate (cf. Hiscott, 1994, 1995; Sohn, 1995, 1997,
1999). With the present state of knowledge,

text:
subdivision of this category of ¯ows and ¯ow
deposits is unwise.
The terms lique®ed and ¯uidized ¯ows are not
included in this ®rst-order classi®cation because
they represent characteristics of the ¯ow related
to either the triggering of hyperconcentrated or

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
concentrated density ¯ows or post-depositional
processes.
Lique®ed
¯ows
(cf.
Middleton
&
Hampton, 1973), in which grains are supported
by trapped or escaping pore ¯uid, will tend to
dissipate and have short run-out or accelerate,
become turbulent and so transform into concen-
trated density ¯ows (cf. Middleton & Southard,
1984).
Steady turbulent ¯ow occurs when the mean
velocity at a point remains unchanged over a
speci®ed time period. In reality, all natural
sediment density ¯ows are unsteady but, in some
situations, mean velocity may be nearly constant
for a period of hours to days. Consequently,
turbidity ¯ows can be subdivided further into
short-duration surges and surge-like ¯ows, in
which the behaviour of the head of the ¯ow is of
primary importance, and more prolonged turbid-
ity currents (quasi-steady ¯ows), when behaviour
of the ¯ow head is of minor importance to deposit
character compared with processes occurring in
the body of the ¯ow. The distinction of duration
is as yet unclear and presents another signi®cant
scienti®c question that should be addressed.
The threshold of duration cannot be stated as a
single value, as the boundary must depend on the
magnitude of the ¯ow. Duration at a point in a
small
surge
or
surge-like
¯ow
(thickness
of
centimetres to metres) may be seconds to minutes,
whereas in large oceanic surge-like ¯ows (scale of
tens to hundreds of metres), it may be hours (e.g.
Grand Banks event over 9 h; Hughes-Clarke et al.,
1990). There is no consensus as to what sedimen-
tary features are the result of the head or body of a
¯ow and, hence, what proportions of features
result from formation by the ¯ow head. Conse-
quently,
exact
classi®cation
is
not
currently
possible. The steadiness of ¯ow also has major
consequences for deposit character (cf. Kneller,
1995). The division into quasi-steady and surge-
like ¯ows is also applicable to concentrated
density ¯ows and, theoretically, to hyperconcen-
trated density ¯ows, although this would require
unusually extreme situations such as prolonged
lahars discharging into tranquil water. Kneller &
Branney (1995) used the concept of sustained
high-density ¯ows to explain deposits of thick
massive sand, and such ¯ows would be quasi-
steady in the present classi®cation.
The erosion, deposition and behaviour of each
of the main ¯ow types de®ned in this classi®ca-
tion are reviewed below and related to the
characteristics of the sediments. In any of these
types of density ¯ows, ¯ow conditions can vary
(in
space
and
time)
between
waxing
(mean

text:
velocity at a point increasing with time) and
waning (mean velocity at a point decreasing with
time) and from accumulative (mean velocity
increasing in the direction of ¯ow) to uniform
(velocity constant along the ¯ow path) and deple-
tive (mean velocity decreasing in the direction of
¯ow) (cf. Kneller, 1995). In addition, different
parts of a ¯ow may be classi®ed in different ways,
and ¯ow transformations can occur in both
time and space. Together, these concepts explain
most, if not all, the recorded characteristics of
subaqueous density ¯ow deposits.

text: COHESIVE FLOWS

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
Cohesive ¯ows are differentiated from all the
other ¯ows discussed in this paper because they
have suf®cient cohesive material (mud) to impart
a pseudoplastic rheology and, hence, reduce the
rate at which they can dilute by either particle
deposition or entrainment of ambient water, and
thus they tend to hold together. A crucial differ-
ence between subaerial and subaqueous debris
¯ows is that, in subaerial conditions, the surface
tension of water menisci produces an added
mechanism to hold the ¯ow together, such that
the volume fraction of cohesive solids required to
produce similar behaviour is different in subae-
rial and subaqueous conditions. There is also a
super®cial difference from the common usage of
`debris ¯ow' and `hyperconcentrated ¯ow' used
in the study of lahars, where the latter are
considered to be more water rich (lower sediment
concentration) than the former with a gradational
boundary at about 50±60% sediment by volume
(Vallance, 2000; Fig. 1). This lahar usage may be
misleading for other subaqueous environments
for two reasons. First, volcanic materials tend to
be poorly sorted and contain less clay compared
with many submarine ¯ows. Secondly, and more
importantly, the idea that lahar hyperconcen-
trated ¯ows are more water rich than debris
¯ow holds true on individual volcanoes where
the sediment source is the same for both types of
¯ow, but may not be the case always when ¯ows
from different volcanoes (with different sediment
characteristics) are compared.
Iverson (1997) suggested that it may be possible
to de®ne the division between viscous debris
¯ows and grain ¯ows in subaerial conditions by
using six non-dimensional numbers. The Darcy
number, NDar, describes the tendency for intersti-
tial pressure developed between moving grains to
buffer grain interactions:

text:
These dimensionless numbers describe ®ve
processes of momentum transport that can sim-
ultaneously affect a steady shear ¯ow: inertial
grain collision, grain contact friction, viscous

text:
shear, inertial (turbulent) ¯uid velocity ¯uctua-
tions and solid±¯uid interactions (Iverson, 1997).
Study of several natural and experimental subae-
rial debris ¯ows allowed Iverson (1985) to de®ne
a range of these non-dimensional numbers in
which the ¯ow can be considered to be a debris
¯ow. Bagnold showed that collisional stresses
dominate viscous stresses if the Bagnold number
is greater than »200 (for an in®nite value of the
Savage number). Savage & Hutter's (1989) experi-
ments demonstrated that grain collision stresses
dominate grain friction stresses in dry granular
¯ows (so the ¯ow becomes a grain ¯ow) if the
Savage number is >0á1. Above a Bagnold number
of 200±450, the ¯ow becomes a more dilute ¯ow
(hyperconcentrated, concentrated ¯ow or turbid-
ity current). This is consistent with a critical
value of 2000 (200/0á1) for the friction number
separating cohesive debris ¯ows from grain ¯ows
in
subaerial
conditions
(Iverson,
1997).
The
Reynolds number is always below 100 (laminar
conditions) in these ¯ows. According to the
de®nition of the mass number, grain inertia
becomes negligible when the density or concen-
tration of grains is close to zero. If concentration
decreases, the ¯ow is no longer a debris ¯ow, thus
justifying the classi®cation based, in part, on
grain concentration or density. Iverson & LaHu-
sen (1989) described experimental debris ¯ows
with Darcy numbers in the range 1000±6000, in
which large ¯uid pressure ¯uctuations are evi-
dence of strong solid±¯uid interactions, consis-
tent with excess pore pressure being the main
triggering factor in subaerial conditions.
In submarine environments, sediment is always
saturated, buoyancy is an important phenomenon
and the critical values of dimensionless numbers,
particularly the Darcy number, may vary from
those found in subaerial environments. However,
it is evident that for a debris ¯ow, according to the
de®nition above, the friction number must be low
and the ¯ow regime laminar.
Cohesion and viscosity are not directly related.
In subaqueous settings, the interstitial water is
generally of the same or lower density than the
ambient water and, consequently, unlike subae-
rial settings, the water within the ¯ow supplies
no driving density to the ¯ow and, because
surface tension is inactive, the interstitial water
does not act to hold the ¯ow together at all.
Consequently, the difference between cohesion
and
viscosity
becomes
more
important,
and
subaqueous and subaerial debris ¯ows cannot be
de®ned in the same way. The use of `reduced
gravity', g(qf±qw)/qw, and effective stress (stress

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
due to particle weight minus stress due to water)
in modelling ¯ow partly overcomes these differ-
ences.
Cohesion between particles results in high
kinematic viscosity (Perret et al., 1995). The
cohesion
provides
`matrix
strength'
(Nardin
et al., 1979; Lowe, 1982), which is the main
grain-support
mechanism,
although
buoyancy
and pore pressure are also important (although
less so than in frictional ¯ows). Liquefaction
(Elverhoi et al., 1997; Major & Iverson, 1999) and
grain interaction may also be locally important
(Pierson, 1981; Iverson et al., 1997; Major &
Iverson, 1999). Hampton's (1975) experiments
suggested that matrix strength is capable of fully
supporting particles up to coarse sand grade.
There
are
numerous
examples,
however,
of
debris ¯ows transporting decametre-scale blocks
(Johnson, 1970, 1984; Rodine & Johnson, 1976;
Leigh & Hartley, 1992; van Weering et al., 1998).
Larger clasts can be supported by high local pore
pressures (Ineson, 1985), buoyancy and clast-to-
clast interaction (Pierson, 1981). As cohesion is
the de®ning attribute of these ¯ows, some may
include relatively little sand.
Cohesive density ¯ows can be divided into
mud ¯ows and debris ¯ows on the basis of the
sediment size sorting. The classi®cation of poorly
sorted sedimentary rocks depends on the per-
centage of gravel-grade sediment and the relative
amounts of sand and mud (Folk, 1954; Moncrieff,
1989). The chosen boundaries in these classi®ca-
tions are arbitrary but, for consistency, distinction
between mud ¯ows and debris ¯ows can follow
similar boundaries. Consequently, assuming that
there is no loss of sediment during or after
deposition, mud-¯ow deposits may be mudstones,
mudstones
with
dispersed
clasts,
clast-poor
diamictite, sandy mudstones or sandy mudstones
with dispersed clasts. Thus, mud ¯ow deposits
have less than 5% gravel by volume and a ratio of
mud to sand of more than 1:1. Mud ¯ows
transport (and so deposit) little or no coarse
sediment, although they may transport isolated
large blocks. Mud ¯ows can be further subdivided
on the basis of the proportion of silt and clay
according to the engineering description of mud-
rocks (Hawkins & Pinches, 1992), such that ¯ows
with <25% clay might be called silty mud ¯ows
and those with >40% clay may be classed as clay-
rich mud ¯ows. Debris ¯ows consist of more
poorly sorted sediment (>5% gravel with variable
sand proportion) and may transport boulder-sized
clasts of soft sediment or rock and very large rafts
or olistoliths (Johnson, 1970, 1984; Rodine &

text:
Johnson, 1976; Leigh & Hartley, 1992; van Weer-
ing et al., 1998; Fig. 5).
Debris ¯ows are known to be able to travel
several hundred kilometres (Gardner & Kidd,
1983; Simm et al., 1991; Gee et al., 1999). Even
though they can travel rapidly (comparable sub-
aerial ¯ows reach speeds of several metres per
second; Middleton & Southard, 1984), subaqu-
eous debris ¯ows generally appear to be only
slightly erosional (cf. Pickering et al., 1989; Gee
et al., 1999). The small amount of erosion and fast
speed has been explained by a water layer being
pinched under the ¯ow snout and reducing the
resistance due to drag on the ¯oor (Iverson, 1997),
thus reducing erosion: this process has been
named hydroplaning (Mohrig et al., 1998, 1999).
Gee et al. (1999) explained the long run-out
distance (700 km) of the Saharan debris ¯ow by
invoking a two-phase ¯ow with a relatively
impermeable upper layer overpressuring a lower,
less cohesive (more mobile) layer.
Debris ¯ows may undergo transformation dur-
ing ¯ow, but such transformations are poorly
understood
(Hampton,
1972;
Weirich,
1988).
Flow transformations have been observed in
subaerial settings (e.g. Pierson & Scott, 1985;
Vallance & Scott, 1997), inferred from the depos-
its of subaqueous events (e.g. Piper et al., 1985,
1992, 1999a) and observed in a small arti®cial
lake (Weirich, 1988). Debris ¯ows may transform
partially or totally into sediment-driven, particu-
late
¯ows.
Flow
transformation
may
occur
through mixing and dilution at the head (Hamp-
ton, 1972), entrainment at the upper boundary of
the body or by passage through a hydraulic jump
(Fisher, 1983; Weirich, 1988). Mixing at the upper
boundary may also generate frictional ¯ows. This
is shown, for example, in a photograph of a
laboratory subaqueous debris ¯ow that has a
mixing cloud above it (Fig. 1 in Mohrig et al.,
1999). Flow transformation has been suggested to
explain several ocean-¯oor features such as those
associated with the 1929 Grand Banks event
(Piper et al., 1985, 1999b), Quaternary features
on the Scotian Slope (Piper et al., 1992) and
Madeira Abyssal Plain (Rothwell et al., 1992).
Debris ¯ows are more likely to transform into
hyperconcentrated density ¯ows or concentrated
density ¯ows if they contain high proportions of
particles larger than medium silt (cf. Hampton,
1972, 1975).
The main process for debris-¯ow deposition is
freezing or en masse deposition of the ¯ow
(Lowe, 1982; Postma, 1986) or parts of the ¯ow.
When the force related to the shear resistance of

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
Fig. 5. Examples of marine debris-¯ow deposits from the Oligo-Miocene of the Pindos foreland basin ®ll, Greece (cf.
Alexander et al., 1990; Leigh & Hartley, 1992). (A) A debris-¯ow deposit within a sequence of thin-bedded sand-
stones and siltstones of the Pindos foreland basin. The interpreted top and bottom of the bed are marked by dashed
lines. The deposit is mainly composed of silty mud with lesser proportions of sand and sandstone clasts that are of
the same character as the adjacent turbidite beds. Exotic lithic pebbles (mostly limestone) occur sporadically through
the deposit (e.g. marked by arrows). Rafts of interbedded sandstone and mudstone are seen towards the bottom of this
exposure, and these are deformed. An isoclinal folded raft is marked by the dashed line. (B) Part of a debris-¯ow
deposit that is about 25 m thick in total. The debris-¯ow deposit is composed of scattered exotic lithic clasts and rafts
and clasts of sandstone and siltstone (some folded as in A) in a silty mud matrix. The photograph shows some of the
variation in matrix character and the concentration of pebbles in discrete layers.

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
the ¯ow (mainly controlled by viscosity and
friction) becomes equal to the force due to gravity
(which is the main driving force in debris ¯ows),
the ¯ow stops (cohesive freezing). The water
content in this kind of ¯ow is low and, therefore,
the thickness of the deposit is relatively close to
the thickness of the ¯ow during motion. Changes
in thickness occur after deposition as a result of
consolidation
and
compaction
below
further
deposits. Despite any post-depositional reduction
in
thickness,
ancient
subaqueous
debris-¯ow
deposits are commonly found to be tens of metres
thick (e.g. Leigh & Hartley, 1992) and have been
recorded up to >200 m thick (Hiscott & James,
1985). The yield strength allows morphological
features such as levees, ¯ow snouts and surface
features
(e.g.
protruding
clasts,
ropy
surface
patterns) to be preserved after the ¯ow stops if

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
they are not subsequently eroded (Hiscott &
James, 1985; Pickering et al., 1989).
En masse deposition explains the relatively
chaotic arrangement of the deposits and the grain-
size distribution that is near to that which was
transported in the ¯ow, although ®ne particles
may be removed during and after deposition by
elutriation. The large variation in grain size,
particle shape and composition that can be
transported by debris ¯ows results in deposits
that are extremely varied (e.g. Fig. 5). Some of the
clasts of more labile material are deformed by the
relatively small-scale shearing within the ¯ow or
by shearing or compaction just after freezing
(Fig. 5A). Although debris-¯ow deposits are char-
acteristically very poorly sorted and may have
few signs of internal structures because of plug
¯ow and en masse deposition, traces of shear

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
fabric may occur near the ¯ow base and margins
and also within the ¯ow because of ¯ow surging
(cf. Major, 1997), and this may also lead to
punctuated bed aggradation in places. Coarse
particles may be concentrated in particular hori-
zons (Fig. 5B) or given a directional fabric as a
result of pulsed shearing within the ¯ow body
(Leigh & Hartley, 1992).

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text: NON-COHESIVE DENSITY FLOWS

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text: Hyperconcentrated density ¯ows

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
Hyperconcentrated density ¯ows may have sim-
ilar proportions of solid and liquid components to
the cohesive ¯ows described above (Fig. 1), but
they behave differently (non-Newtonian but not
plastic) because of the lower proportions of
cohesive grains or possibly because cohesion is
overcome by internal agitation (increased shear
rate) that is caused by high ¯ow velocities or ¯ow
over a rough surface. Hyperconcentrated density
¯ows include ¯ows previously called sandy
debris ¯ows (Shanmugam, 1996, 1997), non-
cohesive (or cohesionless) debris ¯ows (Falk &
Dorsey, 1998), catastrophic ¯ood deposits (Mutti
et al., 1996), inertial grain ¯ows (Takahashi,
1981), grain ¯ows (of which sand ¯ows are a
subclass de®ned by dominant clast size, e.g.
Plink-BjoÈrklund & Ronnert, 1999), debris ava-
lanches (e.g. Voight & Sousa, 1994), grain-¯ow
avalanches (Leeder, 1999) and sand avalanches
(Shepard & Dill, 1966) and may also include some
slurry ¯ows (Lowe & Guy, 2000). Submarine
hyperconcentrated ¯ows have some similarities
to subaerial hyperconcentrated ¯ows that occur,
for example, during ¯ash ¯oods in some semi-arid
mountainous
catchments
(e.g.
Batalla
et al.,
1999), in easily eroded source areas (e.g. Xu,
1998) and in association with some types of
volcanic activity (e.g. Pierson & Scott, 1985).
Subaqueous hyperconcentrated ¯ows may occur
where these subaerial hyperconcentrated ¯ows
discharge into lakes or seas. There is a major
difference between subaqueous and subaerial
hyperconcentrated density ¯ows, however, as
the interstitial ¯uid in the former is the same as,
or very similar to, the ambient ¯uid and, conse-
quently, coherence of the ¯ow body is less (water
aids ¯ow coherence in subaerial hyperconcen-
trated ¯ows). This difference is particularly sig-
ni®cant when considering the boundary between
hyperconcentrated and debris ¯ows. Subaerial
¯ows with low contents of mud-grade material

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text: 13653091, 2001, 2, Downloaded from https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1046/j.1365-3091.2001.00360.x by Bibliothèque de Sorbonne Université, Wiley Online Library on [13/03/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
can ¯ow as lobes and are generally called debris
¯ows (as in the experiments of Iverson, 1997;
Iverson et al., 1997; Major & Iverson, 1999) but
underwater a lot of these ¯ows would behave as
hyperconcentrated
¯ows.
Hyperconcentrated
density ¯ows also include bedload-dominated
under¯ows generated at the mouths of small
streams in mountainous areas in which metre-
sized boulders can be transported. Such stream-
generated hyperconcentrated ¯ows occur in small
basins with shallow water depths, particularly in
tectonically active settings (Mutti et al., 1996). In
this setting, small steep ramps allow transport of
blocks close to the bottom, but ramps are too short
to allow a full transformation of the ¯ow into a
turbidity current. These ¯ows may result in the
progradation of small alluvial fans (cf. Mutti
et al., 1996; Falk & Dorsey, 1998). Hyperconcen-
trated density ¯ows may also be generated at
ice-sheet margins where subglacial or englacial
channels debouch into deep water where such
¯ows may be quasi-steady (cf. Plink-BjoÈrklund &
Ronnert, 1999).
The proportion of cohesive and non-cohesive
particles that de®ne the threshold between cohe-
sive and frictional behaviour is not well known
for subaqueous ¯ow and varies depending on
¯ow conditions and concentration (cf. Fisher,
1971; Iverson, 1997). Shanmugam (1996, 1997)
suggested that a sand proportion greater than
about 25±30% by volume may be required. Sandy
sediment can move as a debris ¯ow with as little
as 2% by volume clay content if the sand is ®ne
grained and 19% by volume if the sand is coarse
grained (Hampton, 1975). Coussot (1992) sugges-
ted that a clay content of 4±10% by volume would
cause a subaerial poorly sorted mixture to behave
as a viscoplastic ¯uid regardless of the maximum
particle size. It has been suggested that debris
¯ows can transform to non-cohesive ¯ows with
no change in water content or clay fraction when
the velocity is high enough (Fisher, 1983) and, as
suggested by Middleton & Southard (1984), the
reverse
transformation
may
also
be
possible
where deceleration or dewatering of a hypercon-
centrated ¯ow generates a debris ¯ow (cf. the
matrix strength-modi®ed grain-¯ow deposits of
Plink-BjoÈrklund & Ronnert, 1999). Such a trans-
ition has been observed in subaerial conditions
(cf. Plafker & Ericksen, 1978
1
) but has not yet been
documented in subaqueous settings.
The character of these frictional ¯ows depends
on the proportion of cohesive and non-cohesive
particles, water content and ¯ow velocity. Julien
& Lan (1991) used natural and experimental data

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
to demonstrate that ¯ow behaviour depended not
only on particle concentration but also on the
relative density of ¯uid and particles and the
particle size.
Frictional ¯ows, in which the ¯uid plays only a
minor part in either triggering the ¯ow (i.e. ¯uid
shear and ¯uidization are not operating) or
transport, have been called grain ¯ows (Nardin
et al., 1979), and these are a subclass of hyper-
concentrated
density
¯ows
(Fig. 3).
In
these
¯ows, grain-to-grain and grain-to-bed collisions
predominate throughout the ¯ow (Jaeger et al.,
1996). Such ¯ows generally require a relatively
steep slope to travel any signi®cant distance and
may form signi®cant volumes of deposits where
clean sand is supplied to submarine canyon
heads, as in the Campos Basin of SE Brazil (Viana
& FaugeÁres, 1998
2
).
The presence of some cohesive grains may
make the generation and maintenance of hyper-
concentrated ¯ows easier, as the rate of pore
pressure dissipation is reduced and coherence of
the ¯ow body is encouraged. Such ¯ows, with
some internal cohesion, may be more common,
larger and travel further than grain ¯ows in which
grain interaction is predominantly non-cohesive.
Flows of this type may include the slurry ¯ows
discussed by Lowe & Guy (2000). This behaviour
and relationship with clay content may be similar
to that reported in lahars (Vallance, 2000).
Liquefaction is a common triggering mechan-
ism for hyperconcentrated density ¯ows and is
considered the most frequent mechanism for
triggering subaerial debris ¯ows (Iverson, 1997).
Liquefaction occurs when the effective resistance
of the granular material is reduced to zero by an
increase in internal pore pressure. This increase
in pore pressure can be caused by storm wave
loading in shallow water depths (e.g. in deltaic
environments; Prior et al., 1989) or when sand is
submitted to seismic shaking. In the latter case,
sediment strength is reduced by an increase in
pore pressure and the generation of ground
acceleration. Liquefaction can also be generated
by high sedimentation rates occurring, for exam-
ple, at river mouths (Bornhold et al., 1994) or by
tidal lowering during equinox tide conditions
(Bjerrum, 1971). Particles in lique®ed sediment
are supported by the upward force of ¯uid
pressure (reducing friction), and the sediment
body has little resistance to downslope move-
ment. In a two-layer system comprising a basal,
easily ¯uidized, high-porosity layer and a less
easily ¯uidized, lower porosity upper layer (such
as reported in the Saharan debris ¯ow; Gee et al.,

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text: 13653091, 2001, 2, Downloaded from https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1046/j.1365-3091.2001.00360.x by Bibliothèque de Sorbonne Université, Wiley Online Library on [13/03/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
1999), liquefaction affects the bottom layer, the
¯ow moves and can then trap increasing amounts
of water below it. The basal water layer is
pressurized by the mass of the upper layer. Such
¯ow behaviour reduces drag at the base of the
¯ow over its full length and encourages hydro-
planing (Mohrig et al., 1998), generating high-
velocity ¯ows with little basal erosion.
The presence
of connected
voids between
grains enables hyperconcentrated density ¯ows
to ingest water, expand and so transform into less
concentrated density ¯ows (and, consequently,
subaqueous ¯ow transformation may be very
different from subaerial equivalents). With few
cohesive particles, turbulence generation is relat-
ively easy (Kneller & Buckee, 2000), and trans-
formation may be triggered by ¯ow over changing
topography, resulting in a concentrated density
¯ow or even a turbidity ¯ow or both (cf. Fisher,
1983).
Flow
transitions
are
associated
with
changing
particle-support
mechanisms
with
increasing ¯uid turbulent support (Fig. 4). Such
transformations may be similar to those observed
in lahars running down river valleys, where
progressive ingress of water at the head dilutes the
mixture, losing the capacity to carry larger gravel
(Vallance, 2000). However, in subaqueous ¯ows,
dilution may also occur along the upper surface
(as shown in a photograph of Taira's experiment
presented by Simpson, 1997, ®g. 16.5, p. 222).
The driving force of hyperconcentrated density
¯ows is mostly related to gravity. Although run-
out distance depends on many factors, such ¯ows
cannot be maintained on very-low-angle slopes
for as long as more dilute ¯ows. The main
mechanism for deposition from hyperconcent-
rated ¯ows is frictional freezing resulting from
grain-to-grain
interaction.
Major
(1997)
used
large-scale subaerial experiments to show that
deposition from granular (frictional) ¯ows was
quite different from that from cohesive ¯ows.
Effectively, en masse freezing does not occur.
Deposition proceeds by the accretion of succes-
sive small-scale ¯ow surges to the top of previous
layers. Transport and segregation of large clasts is
easier than in cohesive ¯ows because upward
movement of particles is not prevented by a
cohesive matrix. Rafting is common and can
transport large blocks over considerable distan-
ces. Relatively little or no normal grading devel-
ops in the deposits of hyperconcentrated ¯ows
because suspension fall-out is relatively unim-
portant. Some inverse grading may develop loc-
ally in some ¯ows either throughout the ¯ow
thickness in the extreme case of grain ¯ows or

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
locally because of the development of traction
carpets (cf. Hiscott, 1994, 1995; Sohn, 1995, 1997,
1999), and this may be emphasized by late or
post-depositional ¯uidization. This inverse gra-
ding is a consequence of both an upward velocity
gradient within the ¯ow and a laminar regime.
Subaerial
hyperconcentrated
¯ows
produce
ungraded or coarse-tail normally graded gravel
or gravelly sand and crudely or thickly strati®ed
sand deposits (cf. Pierson & Scott, 1985; Best,
1992), and similar units will be deposited by
subaqueous hyperconcentrated ¯ows.
Grain-¯ow
deposits
are
typically
massive
coarse silt, sand or gravel with some localized
inverse grading. In the deposits of hyperconcen-
trated ¯ows containing some cohesive material,
¯uidization or liquefaction (cf. Nichols, 1995)
may produce ¯uid escape, collapse and deforma-
tion structures (Lowe & Guy, 2000). Dish struc-
tures may be common, ¯uid escape chimneys
may penetrate the entire deposit thickness, and
vertical clast fabrics may be preserved. Hydro-
planing
may
prevent
basal
erosion
and
the
generation of tractive structures at the base of
some of these ¯ows. Large sediment clasts (mud-
stone clasts, for example) and rafts may be found
within the deposits, and these may be deformed
(often observed to be folded) or undeformed.

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text: Concentrated density ¯ows

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
A variety of particle-support mechanisms oper-
ates in concentrated
density
¯ows,
and the
importance of individual mechanisms varies in
both space and time (Fig. 4). However, in all
concentrated
¯ows,
grain-to-grain
interaction
generating dispersive pressure (Bagnold, 1954)
is a particularly important particle-support mech-
anism, i.e. the energy exchanged by grain colli-
sions helps to maintain them in suspension.
These ¯ows are more dilute than hyperconcen-
trated ¯ows; progressive entrainment of water
causes them to behave as Newtonian ¯uids
(Lowe, 1982). Fluid entrainment is a continuous
phenomenon, and so sediment concentration and
grain-to-grain interaction progressively decrease
from hyperconcentrated density ¯ows to concen-
trated
density
¯ows;
the
physical
threshold
between the two kinds of ¯ow is dif®cult to de®ne,
as it is dependent on the grain size, sorting and
¯ow thickness. In the classi®cation proposed in
the present paper, the boundary is de®ned as the
point at which the dilution of the ¯ow is
suf®cient to (1) allow the upper part of the ¯ow
to be fully turbulent and most, if not completely

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text: 13653091, 2001, 2, Downloaded from https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1046/j.1365-3091.2001.00360.x by Bibliothèque de Sorbonne Université, Wiley Online Library on [13/03/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
all, the ¯ow to be Newtonian; and (2) allow
particle
fall-out
within the
¯ow (differential
settling) such that there is signi®cant sorting
during
the
¯ow
duration.
Consequently,
the
deposits of hyperconcentrated and concentrated
density ¯ows should be different, although one
may evolve into the other with distance or height.
The lower sediment concentration allows excess
pore pressure to dissipate upwards through the
¯ow and so prevents hydroplaning.
The driving force of concentrated density ¯ows
is principally gravity and, because the density of
the ¯ows is considerably higher than the sur-
rounding water, they can achieve high velocities
on steep slopes (cf. the 1979 Nice density ¯ow
documented by Piper & Savoye, 1993; Mulder
et al., 1997b). Concentrated density ¯ows can be
strongly erosional, a feature that may be expected
for ¯ows accelerating in both distance and time
(accumulative waxing ¯ows of Kneller & Branney,
1995). Erosion supplies sediment to the ¯ow and
can be the main source of particles in high-
velocity, sediment-driven ¯ows. Piper & Savoye
(1993) and Mulder et al. (1997b) showed that
erosion by the 1979 Nice density ¯ow contributed
more than 80% of the material recorded in the
®nal deposit. The slope failures observed in the
source
area
of
the
1929
Grand
Banks
¯ow
(Hughes-Clarke et al., 1990) are very shallow
and account for only a small percentage of the
deposited sediment volume. Large scours along
the travel path of the Grand Banks ¯ow suggest
that erosion by the ¯ow was important in main-
taining the excess density and allowing ¯ow.
Evidence for the importance of sediment erosion
in maintaining ¯ow and generating long run-out
distances has been presented from other ¯ow
deposits by Normark & Piper (1991) and Morris
et al. (1998).
Grain-to-grain interaction acts in two ways: it
generates dispersive pressures that contribute to
particle support and also participates in ¯ow
deceleration by dissipating the energy of particles
through non-elastic collisions. Flow motion is a
balance between the driving force (essentially
gravity acting upon density differences) and
grain-to-grain interactions (also related to ¯ow
density by way of sediment concentration). Con-
sequently, there are concentration and velocity
optima, as de®ned by Parker (1982), related to
slope gradient, for which ¯ows can move and
entrain enough water to prevent freezing. The
¯ow ignites (Parker, 1982). If a ¯ow moves down a
very-low-angle slope, such as a prodelta slope or
over a basin ¯oor, the entrainment of water is low,

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
and grain-to-grain interaction may lead to fric-
tional freezing and deposition. If velocity is high
enough, entrainment of sea water progressively
decreases the sediment concentration, despite
erosion, and the ¯ow is prevented from freezing.
With decreasing sediment concentration, ¯uid
turbulence progressively replaces grain-to-grain
interaction as the main particle-support mechan-
ism (as represented in Fig. 4). By de®nition, in
concentrated density ¯ows, the upward compo-
nent of ¯uid turbulence can only contribute part
of the sediment-support mechanism for the sedi-
ment load of the ¯ow as a whole (Fig. 4).
Although grain-to-grain interaction remains the
dominant particle-support mechanism through-
out the total range of concentrated density ¯ows,
¯uid turbulence may act as the main grain-
support mechanism near the top of the ¯ow and
at the ¯ow head (i.e. where entrainment of
surrounding ¯uid occurs; Laval, 1988; Laval
et al., 1988). Such ¯ows may be regarded as
transitional ¯ows, in that the whole ¯ow does not
®t within one ¯ow-type class.
The base of the ¯ow, in some cases, may be
characterized by an intense near-bed transport of
coarse particles (gravel and coarse sand) forming
a traction load. Very close to the bed, particle
concentration is far above the Bagnold limit, and
this part of the ¯ow may behave in a similar way
to
some
hyperconcentrated
density
¯ows,
although additional shear is supplied from the
over-riding concentrated density ¯ow. In con-
trast, at the top of the ¯ow, entrainment and the
development of a mixing cloud leads to a region
with
low
sediment
concentration
(dropping
below the Bagnold limit), and turbulent particle
support dominates. In this way, concentrated
density ¯ows may become strati®ed. The compo-
nent layers have different dominant sediment-
support mechanisms and may decouple (cf. ¯ow
splitting or ¯ow stripping; Piper & Normark,
1983; Masson, 1994) to generate ¯ows of different
character (sediment load characteristics) from the
original ¯ow that may be classi®ed differently
from each other.
The deposits of concentrated density ¯ows may
have an erosional base overlain by massive sand
or gravel as illustrated in Fig. 6 (cf. Ta Bouma or
Lowe sequences).
Under highly
concentrated
basal
layers,
inversely
graded
deposits
may
develop (Lowe, 1982; Hiscott, 1994, 1995; Sohn,
1995, 1997, 1999). Such layers have been des-
cribed from ancient deposits and range in char-
acter from individual thin (<1 cm) layers to
thicker (>10 cm) gravelly layers to repeated 1- to

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text: 13653091, 2001, 2, Downloaded from https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1046/j.1365-3091.2001.00360.x by Bibliothèque de Sorbonne Université, Wiley Online Library on [13/03/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
10-cm-thick layers of alternating inverse grading
and massive sand (cf. Lowe, 1982; Postma et al.,
1988; Pickering et al., 1989). There are several
explanations for different inverse grading styles
(Hiscott, 1994, 1995; Sohn, 1995, 1997, 1999;
Hand, 1997), including moving bed conditions
(cf. Postma et al., 1988) producing traction car-
pets (Lowe, 1988; Pickering et al., 1989; Hiscott,
1994, 1995; Sohn, 1995, 1997, 1999), sediment
supply variation (Hand, 1997) and the conse-
quences of pulsing flow or turbulent sweeps
(Hiscott, 1994, 1995).
In ¯ows or at sites where the basal ¯ow layer
has lower particle concentration, traction features
can develop (cf. unit SI of Lowe, 1982). In these
¯ows and in true turbidity currents (described
below), bedforms can develop if ¯ow conditions
are maintained for long enough. These can be
ripples, dunes or antidune-like bedwaves such as
those that have been described on the distal
¯anks of levees (Cremer, 1983; Savoye et al.,
1993; Migeon, 1997) and beyond channel mouths
(Morris et al., 1998). Deposition from the turbu-
lent upper part (mixing cloud) and tail of the ¯ow
occurs by suspension fall-out leading to Bouma
Tc±e or Td±e facies on top of and off-lapping Ta
facies (for example, see Fig. 6A).
The deposits of hyperconcentrated and con-
centrated density ¯ows can be distinguished from
each other (although there is a continuum) on the
basis of the following:

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
1 The presence or extent of vertical trends in
sediment size and sorting. Some inverse gra-
ding may occur locally (near the base) in both
types of ¯ow deposit, but it is more common
and
can
be
more
pervasive
in
hypercon-
centrated density-¯ow deposits (notably in
grain ¯ows). Hyperconcentrated ¯ows tend to
show little normal grading, although deposits
may be overlain by deposits of associated lower
concentration ¯ows. In contrast, concentrated
density-¯ow deposits may show more pro-
nounced (but crude) normal grading (although
a high proportion of the lower part of a bed may
be massive and locally inverse graded).
2 The presence of erosional features (such as
scours and ¯utes). These are likely to be
developed more extensively under parts of
concentrated ¯ows. Concentrated ¯ows may
attain high velocities, whereas with increasing
velocity, subaqueous hyperconcentrated ¯ows
are likely to transform into concentrated ¯ows.
Concentrated ¯ows are partly turbulent and
may be more prolonged than hyperconcentrated

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
¯ows as the conditions for their generation are
easier to maintain. Both the longer duration
and the greater turbulence allow more erosion.
3 Bedforms and resulting sedimentary structures.
Bedforms may develop and be preserved in
concentrated density-¯ow deposits but are not

text:
common (probably do not occur) in hypercon-
centrated ¯ows (cf. Lowe, 1988).

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
The deposits of concentrated density ¯ows and
turbidity ¯ows may generally be distinguished
from each other (although there is a continuum)
by the following:

text:
Fig. 6. Photographs of beds interpreted as deposits of
concentrated density ¯ows. (A) Photograph of a block
of Eocene sandstone of the Col du Bas, French Alps.
Above the basal erosional surface is a thick massive
gravelly sand (Ta) that passes up into ®ner sand near
the top of the bed (Tb). The overlying, thinner bed has
the same grain-size range (Tab) and shows ripple cross-
strati®cation (Tc). (B) Two concentrated density ¯ow
deposits in the Aberystwyth Grits (Silurian), Newquay,
west Wales. At this site, concentrated density-¯ow
deposits are interbedded with turbidites (e.g. the Tc
unit at the bottom of the photograph) and thin debris-
¯ow deposits (labelled D). The concentrated density-
¯ow deposits have sharp erosional bases and sharp
tops overlain by mudstone. The beds are generally
Bouma Tab, but some are just Tb units. (C) Two Neogene
concentrated density-¯ow deposits from an exposure to
the south of the Gulf of Corinth, Greece. The concen-
trated density-¯ow deposits are within a sequence of
turbidites (example labelled T) and hemipelagic sedi-
ments. Both beds ®ne upwards from a basal erosion
surface. Photographs courtesy of William Higgs. (D)
Concentrated density-¯ow deposits, within the Eocene,
Annot Sandstone, Annot Station, France. The sandy Ta
units of the concentrated density ¯ow deposits have
sharp bases and tops and are interpreted as deposited
from the concentrated bottom of the ¯ow. The silty and
muddy Tde sequence between the two Ta units in this
photograph is interpreted as the deposit from a mixing
cloud above and following the concentrated density
¯ow, but an alternative interpretation is that it is the
deposit of a separate surge-like turbidity current.

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
1 Sediment grade. Most true turbidity currents
do not have the competence to transport large
clasts (such as coarse sand-grade quartz), so
that most density-¯ow deposits of coarse sand
or gravel cannot be the deposits of turbidity
currents sensu stricto. Gravel-grade, low-den-
sity clasts, such as mud or plant material, are
transported more easily and may be incorpor-
ated in turbidites sensu stricto.
2 The thickness of the Ta facies relative to total
deposit thickness, as the proportion of Ta is
generally much greater in concentrated den-
sity-¯ow deposits (compare Figs 6±8).
3 The character of bedforms and sedimentary
structures. Although it is clear that bedform
development depends on sedimentation rate
(e.g. Lowe, 1988), not enough is known about
the variation in sedimentary structure and
fabric with sedimentation rate to use such
variation as a reliable distinguishing feature.
Arnott & Hand (1989) used experiments to
indicate
that
high
deposition
rates
(>0á67 mm s)1) suppressed low-amplitude bed-
waves, which are responsible for the lamin-

text:
ation seen in Bouma Tb divisions, so Tb may be
less common in concentrated density ¯ow
deposits (compare Figs 6 and 7).

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
This classi®cation scheme ®ts the horizontal
evolution of turbidity ¯ows described by Mutti
(1992) or the cut-out sequence of Stow & Piper
(1984). Close to a source, hyperconcentrated
density ¯ows (frictional grain ¯ows) deposit
sediment (Fig. 4). As the ¯ows travel, progressive
¯uid entrainment and dilution cause them to
transform into concentrated density ¯ows. Pro-
gressive transformation tends to improve grading
and decrease the thickness of the Bouma Ta unit.
The proportion of the ¯ow in which grain-to-grain
interaction dominates decreases, whereas the
proportion of the ¯ow in which ¯uid turbulence
is the more important particle-support mechan-
ism increases. Fluid entrainment at the upper
¯ow boundary is proportional to ¯ow boundary
instability (Fukushima et al., 1985) and, at Rich-
ardson numbers less than 0á25 (Simpson, 1997),
Kelvin±Helmholtz billows form and ¯uid entrain-
ment is rapid. The Richardson number is de®ned
as:

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
Ri  qf ÿ qwgh cos a=qwU2
10

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
where h is ¯ow thickness, a is the bed slope and
U is mean velocity, and thus high entrainment
rates tend to occur in fast thin ¯ows. Entrainment
increases with bed slope (Britter & Linden, 1980).
Fast, concentrated density ¯ows ¯owing down
steep slopes erode sediment, accelerate, entrain
water and so `ignite' (Pantin, 1979; Parker, 1982;
Parker et al., 1986). Fast ¯ow can be achieved as a
result of either high slope gradients or ¯ow
channelling in canyons, and such ¯ows may be
supercritical. At some distance from the source,
the ¯ow becomes subcritical and depletive (velo-
city decreases with distance). This transformation
can be controlled by a channel enlargement or
gradient change and may produce a stationary or
near-stationary hydraulic jump (as proposed by
Morris
et al.,
1998
to
explain
bed
features
around the Valencia channel mouth). Beyond
the hydraulic jump, the ¯ow has a lower velocity
(con®rmed, for example, by calculations based on
cable breaks, e.g. Gennesseaux et al., 1980; Nor-
mark & Piper, 1991), and its sediment load is
mostly ®ne grained (®ne sand or ®ner) and fully
transported in suspension. The resulting deple-
tive ¯ow tends to produce Bouma sequences with
progressive changes in sedimentary structures
and grain size (parallel lamination Tb corres-
ponding to the upper ¯ow regime; ripples and

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
cross-bedding, Tc, and parallel lamination, Td,
corresponding to the lower ¯ow regime, draped
by ®ne sediments Te). Progressive settling of
particles or non-uniform distribution of grain size
can explain the lack of individual units of the
Bouma sequence.
It may be possible to subdivide concentrated
density ¯ows into surge, surge-like and quasi-
steady concentrated density ¯ows. Quasi-steady
concentrated density ¯ows have been discussed
by Kneller & Branney (1995) and Kneller (1995),
who termed them sustained high-density turbid-
ity currents. Kneller & Branney (1995) used the
concept of `sustained high-density currents' to
explain deposition of thick massive beds. Because
the difference between long-duration currents and
shorter duration ¯ows is important for under-
standing the nature of the deposits, the present
classi®cation distinguishes between density ¯ows
and density currents such that the latter term is
used to discuss relatively long duration ¯ows.

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text: Quasi-steady concentrated density currents

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
Quasi-steady concentrated density currents can
form when rivers with very high suspended
sediment concentration ¯ow into a larger water
body forming a dense under¯ow current. There
are no published records of such ¯ows, and they
are likely to be rare occurrences but may be
signi®cant in areas of lahar activity or extreme
¯ashy run-off. In addition, because there is an
exponential relationship between sediment con-
centration and water discharge, most of the
suspended sediment at a river mouth is transpor-
ted during major ¯oods, i.e. when hyperpycnal
turbidity currents form (discussed further below).
In most such settings, rapid ¯ow expansion and
convection of the low-density fresh water will
lead to rapid deceleration, decline in transport
capacity and rapid sediment deposition. There-
fore, these currents generally have relatively short
run-out distances from river mouths. The result-
ing deposits are very similar to, and possibly
indistinguishable from, deposits of homopycnal
¯ows. The deposits of quasi-steady concentrated
density currents will tend to be concave up in
stream-parallel pro®le, because of exponential
seaward thinning. These deposits form steeply
dipping, coarse-grained foresets capped by ®ner
topsets with each foreset deposited by a different
event or pulse. Frequently, the generation of a
quasi-steady, concentrated density current will be
associated with development of a quasi-steady
turbidity current and/or a buoyant plume (hypo-
