metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
pycnal ¯ow; cf. interpretations of Falk & Dorsey,
1998). Quasi-steady concentrated density ¯ow is
not discussed further here as it generally has a
short run-out distance, small volume and does not
produce deposits that are described as turbidites.

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text: TURBIDITY FLOWS

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
The etymology of the phrase `turbidity current'
means a turbid ¯ow (i.e. with suspended sedi-
ment), but widely accepted de®nitions of turbid-
ity currents (e.g. Middleton & Hampton, 1973)
state that they are sediment gravity ¯ows in
which the sediment is supported mainly by the
upward component of ¯uid turbulence. In the
present paper, the Bagnold limit for full turbulent
support of sediment (9% sediment concentration
by volume; Bagnold, 1962) is used as the thresh-
old value to de®ne turbidity currents (sensu
stricto), and the Middleton & Hampton (1973)
de®nition,
in
which
sediment
is
supported
mainly by ¯uid turbulence, is used for turbidity
currents (sensu lato). As discussed above, the
term turbidity current is not compatible with the
adjectives `high density' or `high concentration',
as in ¯ows with relatively high sediment concen-
tration, ¯uid turbulence cannot act as the only (or
even main)
particle-support mechanism.
The
resulting misunderstandings (from using phrases
such as `high-density turbidity current') have
been intensi®ed by the widespread use of the
term turbidite (cf. Shanmugam, 1996) meaning
the deposit of a turbidity current. Beds that have
been called turbidites in the literature include a
very large spectrum of ¯ow deposits from cohe-
sive and hyperconcentrated density ¯ows to
turbidites sensu stricto (e.g. Lowe, 1982; Picker-
ing et al., 1989; Clayton, 1994; Droz et al., 1996;
Leeder, 1999), and Kneller & Buckee (2000) argue
for the continuation of this wide usage.
In the classi®cation scheme presented here, a
turbidity current is de®ned as a current in which
¯uid turbulence is the main particle transport
mechanism, although other mechanisms may also
operate to varying degrees (see the variation in
particle-support mechanism represented sche-
matically in Fig. 4). There is a continuum bet-
ween concentrated density ¯ows and turbidity
¯ows; the transformation from one to the other
may be progressive as a result of entrainment and
dilution (as postulated by Hallworth et al., 1993),
and the proportion of total particle support by
¯uid turbulence increases through the transfor-
mation (Fig. 4). Alternatively, turbidity currents

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
can be generated directly (without a precursor
¯ow with a higher sediment concentration) from
suspension clouds generated by, for example,
storm activity on a shelf (Prior et al., 1989) or
rapid run-off.
Turbidity ¯ows can be subdivided on the basis
of their ¯ow behaviour into surge ¯ows, surge-
like turbidity ¯ows and quasi-steady turbidity
currents. Such division is useful because of the
difference in ¯ow character, and also because of
the difference in the nature of the resulting
deposits. The distinction is particularly import-
ant because of the difference in the duration of
the waxing phase (increasing velocity at a point
with time; Kneller, 1995). A distinction can be
made between ¯ows that are very short duration
with no permanent sediment supply (`surge' of
Ravenne & Beghin, 1983 or Laval, 1988) and
currents with sediment supply occurring over a
substantial time period, which permits longer
¯ow duration (quasi-steady conditions). In the
case of a surge, the ¯ow is strongly non-uniform
(velocity varies with distance), and development
of the ¯ow body is negligible (Middleton, 1966).
A current differs from a surge in that it represents
a steady motion of a particular body in which no
boundary (head or tail) is observed. In a quasi-
steady current, the duration of the passage of the
head (or ¯ow front) is very short compared with
the passage of the body, such that the head is
relatively insigni®cant in controlling the nature of
the deposits. The distinction between these ¯ow
types depends on both the duration and the size
of the ¯ow.

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text: Surges and surge-like turbidity ¯ows

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
Surges are very-short-duration ¯ow events that
have the form of a travelling, isolated ¯ow head
(Fig. 3). Such ¯ows are probably uncommon and
may be equivalent to the meteorological phenom-
ena called `terminal clouds', which are generated
from instantaneous sources on inclined boundar-
ies (cf. Beghin et al., 1981). In this situation, any
body of the ¯ow accelerates forward into the head
leaving a dilute tail. Surges may also have
similarities to vortex rings described by Simpson
(1997).
Surge-like ¯ows are also short duration but may
include a short ¯ow body following the head.
Such turbidity ¯ows are probably most often
triggered by ¯ow transformation through erosion
and acceleration (ignition) from a ¯ow type with
higher sediment concentration. Surge-like turbid-
ity ¯ows may also be generated by collapse of a

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text: 13653091, 2001, 2, Downloaded from https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1046/j.1365-3091.2001.00360.x by Bibliothèque de Sorbonne Université, Wiley Online Library on [13/03/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
suspension cloud generated over a short time
period (e.g. suspension on the shelf as a result of
intense storm activity) or reconcentration of a
nepheloid layer by a process such as density
cascading (Postma, 1969; Wilson & Roberts, 1995).
When surges or surge-like turbidity ¯ows have
evolved from another ¯ow type (as the ®nal stage
of the series, cf. Fig. 4), they often travel over
lower slope angles than the associated more
concentrated ¯ows. For example, in the 1979
Nice event, the ¯ow-slide travelled down steep
canyon slopes (>15°), the concentrated density
¯ow continued down slopes of 3° for at least
40 km from the original failure, and the ®nal part
of the travel path, representing another 140 km,
was probably a true turbulent suspension ¯ow.
On the
lobe,
the ¯ow
®nally ¯attened and
reconcentrated to become a new concentrated
¯ow (Unterseh, 1999). Surges and surge-like
turbidity ¯ows (when not co-existing with a basal
concentrated density ¯ow) are mainly deposi-
tional. These ¯ows do not usually transport
particles with grain sizes larger than sand, unless
they are of low density such as animal tests (cf.
Morris et al., 1998). Particles are maintained in
suspension as a result of the upward component
of turbulence and settle gently, with some move-
ment
along
the
bed,
producing
sedimentary
structures and bedforms of typical Bouma Tb±d.
If particles are sand grade, ¯ow may reconcentrate
and form a concentrated sheet ¯ow spreading
along the base as a lobe (leading perhaps to
transitional deposits as shown in Fig. 7B). Ero-
sion can be produced at the base of turbidity
¯ows when the ¯ow is reaccelerated. Reacceler-
ation can occur with an increase in slope, for
example when a current ¯ows over a levee
(Migeon,
1997;
Fig. 7A)
or
when
a
channel
narrows.
Surges and shorter duration surge-like ¯ows are
very-short-duration events; hence, variation in
depositional
conditions
with
time
may
not
always be appreciated from their deposits. These
¯ows are similar to powder snow avalanches and
carry a small amount of sediment in relation to
the total ¯ow volume. Individually, surges and
shorter duration surge-like ¯ows will not produce
thick deposits unless the ¯ow magnitude is very
large or ¯ow is ponded (cf. Rothwell et al., 1992)
and, even then, the bed thickness is relatively
small compared with the ¯ow size (small ratio of
bed thickness to bed length). In many cases, the
deposits of surges and shorter duration surge-
like ¯ows may be hard to recognize in the
sedimentological record, because thin ®ne beds

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
(sometimes only laminae) may not be easily
distinguished from other ®ne sediments (pelagic,
hemipelagic or contourite), and thin beds may be
later homogenized by bioturbation or be com-
pletely eroded. Bedforms and related sedimentary
structures (Bouma Tb±d) may be rare in surges and
short-duration surge-like turbidity-¯ow deposits,
as bedforms take time to develop and the duration
of bedform-generating conditions might be too
short for recognizable features to form. On the
other hand, longer duration ¯ows (surge-like
turbidity ¯ows) can develop a long ¯ow body,
which will be both non-uniform and unsteady
(velocity varies with both time and distance). The
head and a part of the body are usually waxing
and may be erosive (Kneller, 1995), whereas the
rest of the body and tail are waning. These surge-
like ¯ows tend to deposit well-developed Bouma
Tb±d facies.

text:
Fig. 7. (A) Photograph of Holocene
spill-over turbidite deposits on the
Var sedimentary levee (NW Mediter-
ranean Sea, France) at about 2400 m
water depth taken during the dive of
the Cyana (Ifremer submersible) dur-
ing the 1986 SAME cruise. Turbidites
are the dark layers (thickness about
0á1 m). Hemipelagites are the pale
layers. Photograph courtesy of Bruno
Savoye. (B) An Eocene density cur-
rent deposit from Lac du Lauzanier,
French Alps. The bed consists of a Tae
Bouma sequence interpreted as the
deposit of a concentrated density ¯ow
(at the lower end of the concentration
range) or of a transitional ¯ow (part
concentrated density ¯ow and part
turbidity ¯ow). A pebbly layer at the
base (Ta) probably formed during
passage of the erosive ¯ow head, and
the upper part of the deposit (Tb±d)
was deposited by the tail of the ¯ow
that had the character of a true
turbidity ¯ow. The tape measure is
about 1 cm wide.

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
Some surge-like turbidity currents are caused
by multiple retrogressive foreset failures of sand-
bars at river mouths that are related to ¯ood
conditions. During ¯ood run-off, when sediment
concentration at the river mouth is too low to
produce a hyperpycnal turbidity current directly,
sedimentation rate may be raised enough to cause
rapid sandbar construction and migration (Born-
hold
et al.,
1994).
Oversteepening
of
freshly
deposited, underconsolidated sediment produces
frequent, retrogressive foreset failures during and
just after the ¯ood event, creating small-scale
¯ows. Because they are related to ¯ooding peri-
ods, turbidity currents have been reported as a
frequent
phenomenon
by
numerous
authors
including Shepard et al. (1977) on La Jolla deep-
sea fan, Gennesseaux et al. (1971) in the Var
Canyon, Prior et al. (1986, 1987) and Bornhold
et al. (1994) in western Canadian river fjords and

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
Droz et al. (1996) on the Zaire deep-sea fan. The
deposits of these repeated surge-like ¯ows might
be confused with those of quasi-steady hyperpyc-
nal turbidity currents (described below). How-
ever, these surge-like currents have an original
density close to that of the bottom sediment, and
the ¯ow density decreases along the travel path.
As a consequence, the behaviour of these ¯ows
(velocity, erosion) and their deposits are dis-
tinctly different from those of the hyperpycnal,
river mouth-related quasi-steady turbidity cur-
rents described below.

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text: Quasi-steady hyperpycnal turbidity currents

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
Quasi-steady
hyperpycnal
turbidity
currents
form where a river discharges into a basin where
the bulk density of the ef¯uent (sediment and
water)
is
greater than
that
of
the
receiving
ambient water, and thus ¯ow continues from
the river onto the ¯oor of the receiving basin.
Hyperpycnal is used to mean `above a density
threshold' and not simply `high density'. In this
sense, and following Mulder & Syvitski (1995),
hyperpycnal turbidity currents are synonymous
with
suspended
load-dominated
hyperpycnal
currents,
and
the
term
hyperpycnal
current
should
be
restricted
to
¯ows
of
this
type.
Bedload-dominated currents from stream mouths
(Mutti et al., 1996) cannot be considered as
turbidity currents. Hyperpycnal turbidity cur-
rents are termed quasi-steady, as the ¯ow is fed
by prolonged river ¯ow with a duration of hours
to months (Mulder & Syvitski, 1995, 1996), such
that the deposit volume mostly represents body
conditions and the ¯ow front is unimportant.
Quasi-steady hyperpycnal turbidity currents fre-
quently develop in lakes (reported ®rst by Forel,
1885, 1892 in Lake LeÂman) where very little
suspended sediment is needed in the ¯uvial
ef¯uent to produce excess density. When rivers
discharge into marine basins, depending on the
temperature and salinity at the river mouth,
36±44 kg m)3 of suspended sediment is required
to produce a hyperpycnal plume (Mulder &
Syvitski,
1995,
1996).
In
contrast,
turbidity
currents generated within the marine environ-
ment have saline interstitial water, and sediment
concentrations as low as 1±2 kg m)3 are suf®-
cient to maintain a current on a slope (e.g. as
reported in the Var Canyon, Gennesseaux et al.,
1971).
Hyperpycnal turbidity currents, by de®nition,
have sediment concentrations lower than con-
centrated density ¯ows and, generally, also less

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text: 13653091, 2001, 2, Downloaded from https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1046/j.1365-3091.2001.00360.x by Bibliothèque de Sorbonne Université, Wiley Online Library on [13/03/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
than many surge-like turbidity ¯ows that evolve
from concentrated density ¯ows (Mulder et al.,
1998). As a consequence of the lower sediment
concentrations, assuming the same ambient ¯uid,
hyperpycnal turbidity currents generally have
lower velocities than other ¯ow types.
A major difference between quasi-steady ¯ows
and surge-like
¯ows
is the
duration of the
phenomena relative to its magnitude. The dur-
ation of a surge-like ¯ow can be a few tens of
hours in a rare large event, taking into account the
period from the initial slide to ®nal deposition in
the most distal part (cf. Hughes-Clarke et al.,
1990). For an observer located at a particular
point, the event lasts a few hours at most if the
current
results
from
continuous
retrogressive
slides, and the ¯ow is strongly unsteady. In
contrast, a quasi-steady turbidity current can
persist for several days or weeks, depending on
the ¯ood duration at the river mouth (Skene et al.,
1997; Mulder et al., 1998). To an observer at a
particular point, the phenomenon appears to be
steady for a prolonged period, particularly if the
¯ood hydrograph rises and falls gradually. The
¯ow may be uniform or non-uniform over a long
distance, depending on the slope and initial
momentum (e.g. Fig. 8).
Unfortunately, this ¯ow type has been little
studied, and so interpretation of ancient deposits
is very dif®cult. A few studies have examined
arti®cial quasi-steady turbidity currents where,
for example, mine tailings are discharged into the
sea (e.g. Hay, 1987; Normark, 1989). There are a
few studies that have suggested hyperpycnal
turbidity currents as an explanation for observed
deposits (e.g. Nemec, 1995; Piper et al., 1999a),
but diagnostic criteria for their identi®cation have
not been established.
During the rise of a ¯ood, the rate of velocity
increase at a river mouth depends on the origin
of the ¯ood (storm, monsoon and prolonged
rainfalls), rainfall pattern and catchment beha-
viour (rating coef®cient). If the near-shore slope is
relatively steep or if the ¯ow is channelled
(lateral ¯ow restriction), the ¯ow is accumulative
(Kneller, 1995) and reworks its own deposits
(Fig. 9B and C). In the case of a ¯ash ¯ood,
insigni®cant deposition occurs in areas where the
¯ow is waxing because the initial velocity increa-
ses quickly and deposits are immediately re-
worked. Once past the base-of-slope or where the
¯ow is no longer channelled, the ¯ow becomes
depletive and almost steady because the increase
in initial velocity at the river mouth is attenuated.
In these sites, sediments then can be deposited

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
and preserved, and a coarsening-up pro®le is
expected
during
the
waxing
phase
(Kneller,
1995); such a sequence has been described from
the Saguenay Fjord, Canada (Syvitski & Schafer,
1996; Mulder et al., 1998). As the ¯ow continues
to wax, deposition progrades, and the zone of
erosion moves seawards so that areas that were
initially depositional may become erosional.
As the ¯ood wanes, the site of maximum
deposition
moves
landwards.
Near
the
river

text:
Fig. 8. Evolution of ¯ow velocity,
density and volume concentration of
hyperpycnal turbidity currents. The
velocity graph shows accumulative
¯ow near the river mouth and deple-
tive ¯ow in distal areas.

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
mouth, if slopes are steep or if the ¯ow is
channelled, the ¯ow becomes accumulative and
waning. More distally, the ¯ow becomes deple-
tive and waning. The resulting waning ¯ow
deposits are morphologically identical to those
deposited by surge-like turbidity ¯ows (e.g. Bou-
ma sequences) but may be thicker as the waning
period may be more prolonged. Depending on the
duration of the ¯ood, large amounts of sediment
may be deposited. The Saguenay Fjord hyperpyc-

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
Fig. 9. Shape of hyperpycnal turbi-
dites deposited by quasi-steady tur-
bidity currents shown in ¯ow-parallel
section. The three diagrams represent
some of the variation in vertical
sequences of component facies that
are expected in such deposits, inclu-
ding coarsening-up to ®ning-up se-
quences, simple ®ning-up sequences
and bypass surfaces draped by ®ne
sediment. In any one deposit, sedi-
ment coarsens up and then ®nes up at
some sites, but simply ®nes upwards
at others. The diagrams represent the
deposits of quasi-steady turbidity
currents with (A) no erosion, (B)
moderate erosion and (C) intense
erosion. The size of stipple correlates
with relative grain size.

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
nal turbidite (Syvitski & Schafer, 1996) reaches a
maximum thickness of 10±12 m some 37 km from
the river mouth.
The consequence of variation in ¯ood hydro-
graph shape and sediment ¯ux patterns between
¯oods and between rivers, with the variation in
conditions with distance from a river mouth,
results in very varied sedimentary sequences;
these are probably far more varied, because of the
variation in ¯ood hydrographs, than with any
other density-¯ow type. The deposits range from
inversely graded units overlain by a normally
graded sequence, through a similar sequence but
with a thick uniform grain-size interval (resulting
from steady conditions) to various sequences in
which the inversely graded unit is partly or
totally eroded before deposition of a normally
graded unit (cf. Fig. 9). Increasing amounts of
within-bed
erosion
(partial
removal
or
total
removal of inversely graded units) occur in
proximal positions (Skene et al., 1997; Mulder
et al., 1998).
It might be possible to recognize quasi-steady
turbidity current deposits by a coarsening-up unit
followed by a ®ning-up unit separated by a sharp
contact or erosional surface, at least in proximal
areas (cf. the Saguenay turbidite; Mulder et al.,
1998). Depending on the magnitude of the ¯ood,
the inversely graded part of the turbidite may not
be preserved in the most proximal area. Intense
erosion in the proximal part of the plume during
the rising limb of a ¯ood may affect the overall
shape of the deposits and, if the deposit is thick
enough, might be an important feature for the
recognition of quasi-steady turbidites on seismic
re¯ection pro®les. If little erosion occurs in
proximal areas while deposition is occurring in
more distal regions of a hyperpycnal turbidity
current, the resulting deposits are likely to have a
gently concave-up shape (Fig. 9A). When erosion
occurs, some of the proximal parts of the deposit
tend to be removed and redeposited seawards; the
amplitude of erosion decreases seawards. In cases
in which erosion is intense, deposits are convex-
up (bell-shaped, Fig. 9C) as exempli®ed by the
Saguenay turbidite (Mulder et al., 1998).
The Saguenay turbidite includes an inversely
graded unit capped by a normally graded unit in
the distal part. The inversely graded part of the
Saguenay turbidite and other similar deposits is
usually thinner than the normally graded part
because (1) it involves only the coarser sediment
fraction; (2) it may have been eroded, or partly
eroded, during peak ¯ood conditions; and (3) the

text: 13653091, 2001, 2, Downloaded from https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1046/j.1365-3091.2001.00360.x by Bibliothèque de Sorbonne Université, Wiley Online Library on [13/03/2025]. metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
rising limbs of ¯oods are usually shorter than the
falling limbs.
At locations where the ¯ow is both steady and
depletive, thick deposits can form, and climbing
ripples may develop when the ¯ow velocities
are low (ranging from a few centimetres to about
a metre per second depending on Froude num-
ber). Climbing ripples may be a major sedimen-
tary feature of hyperpycnal turbidites, as they
represent the steady migration of sedimentary
bedforms while sediment supply is maintained
and
sedimentation
rate
is
signi®cant.
When
sediment load decreases, climbing ripples can
be
replaced
by
classical
asymmetric
ripples
producing cross-lamination. Dunes will be less
common, as the conditions favourable for their
formation may be maintained for a shorter time,
and bigger bedforms take longer to develop.
Climbing ripples have been observed in in-
versely graded units that are capped by normally
graded
units
in
the
Var
sedimentary
ridge
(Migeon,
1997),
where
hyperpycnal
turbidity
currents are expected to be frequent (Mulder
et al., 1997b). The low sediment concentration
in
hyperpycnal
turbidity
currents
compared
with most of the rest of the sediment-driven
¯ows described in this paper, and consequent
low velocities, allow large volumes of ¯uid
entrainment over short distances and vertical
¯ow expansion. As a result, hyperpycnal tur-
bidity currents can become very thick ¯ows, and
this may be one explanation for the discovery of
`turbidites' on topographic highs, such as on
levee tops bordering submarine canyons (Piper &
Savoye,
1993)
downstream
of
river
mouths
where hyperpycnal plumes are suspected to be
generated with a high frequency, such as in the
Var Canyon (Mulder et al., 1997b).
Hyperpycnal turbidity currents generated at
river mouths transport sediment directly from
the continent towards the ocean. Consequently,
both the volume and the origin of organic matter
may be different from those found in other
settings: deposits may contain few marine taxa
and are likely to contain large percentages of
allochthonous freshwater fossils.
Given the frequency of their formation, hyper-
pycnal turbidites are probably very common,
although they are not commonly recorded in the
literature. Misidenti®cation could occur for two
reasons: (1) lack of the basal inversely graded unit
as a result of erosion or bypass and their conse-
quent misinterpretation in terms of classical
Bouma-type sequences that are related to surge-
like turbidity ¯ows; and (2) interpretation as two

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
separate beds, the bottom one related to a con-
centrated density ¯ow and the upper one to a
surge-like turbidity current.

text: CONCLUSIONS

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
Density ¯ows are responsible for a very large
percentage of the subaqueous sediment transpor-
ted basinwards. The literature on subaqueous
density ¯ows and their deposits is confused by
misuse and contradictory application of terms in
published classi®cations and the generally poor
understanding of ¯ow and depositional mecha-
nisms. The classi®cation presented here aims to
reduce this confusion and identi®es areas that are
particularly poorly understood. This classi®ca-
tion divides ¯ows on the basis of the cohesivity of
the particles, ¯ow duration, sediment concentra-
tion and particle-support mechanism. These fac-
tors all in¯uence the nature of the deposits and so
may be used to help identify ¯ow type from
ancient deposits.
The classi®cation formally divides subaqueous
density ¯ows into cohesive ¯ows and frictional
¯ows (Figs 1 and 3). Subaqueous cohesive ¯ows
are divided into debris ¯ows and mud ¯ows on
the
basis
of
the
sediment
size
distribution,
whereas mud ¯ows are subdivided into clay-rich
and silty mud ¯ows. Frictional ¯ows are subdi-
vided into hyperconcentrated density ¯ows, con-
centrated density ¯ows and turbidity ¯ows, and
these are further subdivided on the basis of
duration into surges, surge-like ¯ows and quasi-
steady currents. When applying any classi®cation
scheme of sedimentary density ¯ows, it should be
kept in mind that ¯ow transformations are com-
mon (cf. Fisher, 1983), and one ¯ow may change
type both with distance (down and across ¯ow)
and with time at any one point.
The
classi®cation
highlights
some
speci®c
points:

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
1 The threshold condition(s) for transition to or
from cohesive and non-cohesive ¯ows is poorly
de®ned. Iverson (1997) de®ned six dimension-
less numbers that are probably the most rele-
vant for de®ning boundaries and describing the
transition from subaerial high-concentration
cohesive ¯ows to subaerial high-concentration
frictional ¯ows. The application of these di-
mensionless numbers to subaqueous ¯ows has
not been adequately investigated. Although
cohesion and viscosity are not directly related
and the critical numbers might vary between

text: 13653091, 2001, 2, Downloaded from https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1046/j.1365-3091.2001.00360.x by Bibliothèque de Sorbonne Université, Wiley Online Library on [13/03/2025]. metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
subaerial and subaqueous conditions, these
dimensionless numbers may be useful for the
investigation of ¯ow thresholds.
2 The threshold between hyperconcentrated and
concentrated density ¯ow is based on the
transition from conditions in which differen-
tial particle settling may occur freely within
the ¯ow. The transition depends on particle
concentration and probably also on grain size
distribution and viscosity, although their ef-
fects are as yet poorly de®ned. The boundary
between hyperconcentrated and concentrated
density ¯ow may be near the transition from
non-Newtonian to Newtonian behaviour.
3 Using Bagnold's limit to de®ne turbidity ¯ows
is satisfactory but, as there is probably a
continuous range from ¯ows with a ¯uid
turbulent
sediment
support
to
those
with
grain-to-grain support, and these may occur
in different areas of the same ¯ow, application
of this de®nition is dif®cult. Additionally, as
the difference in characteristics of deposits
across the Bagnold limit is unknown, it is best
to de®ne turbidity currents (sensu lato) as
¯ows in which particle support by ¯uid turbu-
lence is dominant, rather than being the only
mechanism.
4 Turbidity ¯ows and concentrated density ¯ows
can be subdivided into surges, surge-like tur-
bidity currents and quasi-steady turbidity cur-
rents. This distinction is compatible with the
difference between ¯ows generated by trans-
ition from other density ¯ows or by collapse of
suspension clouds (e.g. storm generated) and
those currents caused by sustained suspended-
sediment-charged ¯uvial discharge.
5 Surge-like
turbidity
¯ows
generate
typical
Bouma sequences, whereas quasi-steady tur-
bidity currents are relatively long duration,
steady ¯ows and may produce a range of
sequences
that
typically
comprise
a
basal
coarsening-up
unit
capped
by
a
®ning-up
Bouma-like unit. An erosional surface or a
sharp contact may separate the coarsening-up
and ®ning-up units and may locally remove the
entire bottom unit. At locations where the ¯ow
is both steady and depletive, thick units of
uniform character can be deposited, and climb-
ing ripples may develop.

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
The main potential problem with this new
classi®cation scheme is in restricting the term
`turbidity current' to low-concentration density
¯ows. For this point of view to be largely
accepted and used, the term `turbidite' should

metadata.source_doc: Sedimentology - 2001 - Mulder - The physical character of subaqueous sedimentary density flows and their deposits.pdf

text:
also be restricted to deposits of turbidity currents
in order to emphasize the relationship between
the deposit and the sediment transport processes.
Deposits that can be interpreted in terms of
Bouma sequences are not all related to turbidity
¯ows. Although bottom cut-out sequences are
probably always related to turbidity ¯ows, some
of the top cut-out sequences and, in particular,
the widespread isolated Ta or Tab deposits, are
usually the result of concentrated density ¯ows.
Lowe sequences result from concentrated density
¯ows that include some turbulence in their
particle-support mechanism (at least during the
depositional period) and should be classi®ed as
concentrated
density-¯ow
deposits.
For
true
turbidites, an accurate terminology should differ-
entiate
Bouma-like
turbidites
resulting
from
surge-like turbidity ¯ows and deposits of quasi-
steady turbidity currents.
